focus_skills: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 12 from both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. Then divide both sides by 5: <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations in reverse order of operations.

questions.question: A bookstore offers a 25% discount on all books. If a book originally costs $48, what is the sale price after the discount?
questions.explanation: The discount amount is <math><mn>25</mn><mi>%</mi></math> of <math><mn>48</mn></math>, which is <math><mn>0.25</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. The sale price is <math><mn>48</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> dollars.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that the sale price = original price − discount amount. Alternatively, calculate sale price directly as (100% − discount%) × original price.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A recipe requires 3 cups of flour for every 2 cups of sugar. If a baker uses 9 cups of flour, how many cups of sugar are needed?
questions.explanation: Set up a proportion: <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac></math>. Cross-multiply: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. Divide both sides by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When working with ratios, set up a proportion and solve by cross-multiplication.

questions.question: A rectangular garden has a length of 15 meters and a width of 8 meters. What is the area, in square meters, of the garden?
questions.explanation: The area of a rectangle is length × width: <math><mn>15</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math> square meters.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize basic area formulas: rectangle = length × width, triangle = ½ × base × height, circle = πr².

questions.question: The line represented by the equation <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math> is shifted up 4 units. What is the equation of the new line?
questions.explanation: Shifting a line up by 4 units means adding 4 to the y-intercept. The original y-intercept is -7, so the new y-intercept is -7 + 4 = -3. The slope remains unchanged. The new equation is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: A vertical shift affects the constant term (y-intercept) in the equation y = mx + b.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='200' y='285' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>Number of Books Read</text><text x='30' y='150' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90 30,150)' text-anchor='middle'>Frequency</text><rect x='60' y='170' width='60' height='80' fill='#aaccff' stroke='black'/><text x='90' y='165' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial'>4</text><text x='90' y='270' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>0-10</text><rect x='130' y='110' width='60' height='140' fill='#aaccff' stroke='black'/><text x='160' y='105' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial'>7</text><text x='160' y='270' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>10-20</text><rect x='200' y='150' width='60' height='100' fill='#aaccff' stroke='black'/><text x='230' y='145' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial'>5</text><text x='230' y='270' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>20-30</text><rect x='270' y='70' width='60' height='180' fill='#aaccff' stroke='black'/><text x='300' y='65' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial'>9</text><text x='300' y='270' text-anchor='middle' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>30-40</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A histogram with four bins showing the number of books read. Bin 0-10 has frequency 4. Bin 10-20 has frequency 7. Bin 20-30 has frequency 5. Bin 30-40 has frequency 9.
questions.question: The histogram above shows the distribution of the number of books read by students in a summer reading program. In which interval does the median number of books read lie?
questions.explanation:
To find the median interval, first calculate the total number of students.

1. **Total Frequency:** Sum the heights of the bars: 4+7+5+9=25.

2. **Median Position:** The median is the value in the middle. For n=25, the position is 25+12=13 (the 13th student).

3. **Locate the 13th Value:** Count cumulatively from the left:
- Interval 0-10: 4 students (Cumulative: 4)
- Interval 10-20: 7 students (Cumulative: 4+7=11)
- Interval 20-30: 5 students (Cumulative: 11+5=16)

The 13th student falls within the cumulative count of 16, which corresponds to the **20-30** interval.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To locate the median in a histogram or frequency table, calculate the total count <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>, find the middle position <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, and add the frequencies cumulatively until you reach that position.

questions.question: Which of the following is a solution to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Set each factor equal to zero: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></math>; <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Among the choices, 2 is a solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratic equations, try factoring first. Look for two numbers that multiply to the constant term and add to the coefficient of the linear term.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 300,80' fill='#f0f0f0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><polyline points='280,200 280,180 300,180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='90' y='210' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='310' y='210' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='310' y='75' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='220' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>10</text><text x='315' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='190' y='130' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='130' y='195' font-family='Arial' font-size='16' font-weight='bold' fill='black'>θ</text><path d='M 125 200 A 25 25 0 0 0 122 187' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle ABC where angle B is the right angle. The horizontal leg AB has length 10. The vertical leg BC has length 6. The hypotenuse AC is labeled x. Angle A is labeled θ.
questions.question: In the right triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown, angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is labeled <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>θ</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation:
In a right triangle, the tangent of an angle is the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the adjacent side (tan(θ)=oppositeadjacent).

1. Identify the sides relative to angle θ:
- Opposite side (BC) = 6
- Adjacent side (AB) = 10

2. Set up the ratio:
tan(θ)=610

3. Simplify the fraction:
610=35.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the mnemonic **SOH CAH TOA**: **T**angent = **O**pposite / **A**djacent.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add the two equations to eliminate y: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving systems, look for opportunities to add or subtract equations to eliminate one variable.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels 270 miles in 4.5 hours. What is its average speed, in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance ÷ total time = <math><mn>270</mn><mo>÷</mo><mn>4.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> miles per hour.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Average speed is total distance divided by total time. Make sure units are consistent.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></math> for all <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the numerator: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Then <math><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, provided <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look to factor numerators and denominators in rational expressions to simplify. Remember to note domain restrictions.

questions.question: A bag contains 5 red marbles, 7 blue marbles, and 8 green marbles. If one marble is chosen at random, what is the probability that it is NOT blue?
questions.explanation: Total marbles = 5 + 7 + 8 = 20. Number of marbles that are NOT blue = 5 (red) + 8 (green) = 13. Probability = <math><mfrac><mn>13</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Probability of an event not happening is 1 minus the probability of it happening. You can also count favorable outcomes directly.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><path d='M 150 150 L 250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 200 63.4 Z' fill='#e0e0e0' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='165' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>60°</text><text x='200' y='110' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>Area = 24π</text><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='250' y2='150' stroke='black'/><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='200' y2='63.4' stroke='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with a shaded sector. The central angle of the sector is labeled 60 degrees. The area of the sector is labeled 24 pi.
questions.question: A sector of a circle has a central angle of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and an area of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>24</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the circumference of the circle?
questions.explanation:
To find the circumference, first determine the radius r using the area of the sector.

1. **Set up the Area Formula:** The area of a sector is proportional to the central angle.
Area=θ360×πr2

2. **Solve for r2:** Substitute the known values:
24π=60360πr2
24=16r2
r2=144
So, r=12.

3. **Calculate Circumference:**
C=2πr=2π(12)=24π.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that the ratio of the sector area to the total circle area is the same as the ratio of the central angle to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>360</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.

questions.question: Which number line represents the solution to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math>?

options.A: A closed circle at 5, shaded to the left.
options.B: A closed circle at 5, shaded to the right.
options.C: A closed circle at 15/3, shaded to the left.
options.D: A closed circle at 15/3, shaded to the right.

questions.explanation: Solve the inequality: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. This means all numbers less than or equal to 5. On a number line, this is a closed circle at 5 with shading to the left.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When graphing inequalities on a number line: < or > use an open circle; ≤ or ≥ use a closed circle. Shade in the direction of the inequality.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrowhead' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='7' refX='0' refY='3.5' orient='auto'><polygon points='0 0, 10 3.5, 0 7' fill='black'/></marker></defs><line x1='20' y1='100' x2='380' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><line x1='50' y1='280' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><path d='M 70 50 Q 200 450 330 50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><circle cx='200' cy='250' r='4' fill='black'/><text x='370' y='120' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='30' y='30' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>y</text><text x='210' y='250' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>Vertex (h, k)</text><text x='60' y='120' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>O</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A coordinate plane with a parabola opening upwards. The vertex is located in the fourth quadrant (positive x, negative y). The parabola crosses the x-axis at two distinct points.
questions.question: The graph of the quadratic function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math> is a parabola. If the parabola opens upward and its vertex <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> lies in Quadrant IV (where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>), which of the following statements must be true about the coefficients <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>b</mi></math>, and the discriminant <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Δ</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
Analyze the conditions:
1. **Opens Upward:** This implies a>0.
2. **Vertex x-coordinate:** The x-coordinate of the vertex is h=-b2a. Since the vertex is in Quadrant IV, h>0. Since a>0, for the entire fraction to be positive, b must be negative (b<0).
3. **Roots (Discriminant):** The vertex y-coordinate is negative (k<0) and the parabola opens upward. This means the graph must cross the x-axis twice. Two distinct real roots implies the discriminant Δ=b2-4ac is positive (Δ>0).

Therefore, a>0, b<0, and Δ>0.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall that the axis of symmetry is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>. The sign of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>b</mi></math> depends on both the location of the vertex and the sign of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrowhead' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='7' refX='0' refY='3.5' orient='auto'><polygon points='0 0, 10 3.5, 0 7' fill='black'/></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='380' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrowhead)'/><text x='215' y='290' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>Hours on Social Media</text><text x='15' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' transform='rotate(-90,15,140)' text-anchor='middle'>Test Score</text><circle cx='90' cy='80' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='140' cy='110' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='190' cy='150' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='250' cy='190' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='320' cy='230' r='4' fill='black'/><line x1='90' y1='80' x2='320' y2='230' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with a line of best fit showing a strong negative linear relationship between Hours on Social Media (x-axis) and Test Score (y-axis).
questions.question: The scatterplot above shows the relationship between the number of hours a student spends on social media per day, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, and their test score, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>. The line of best fit for the data passes through the points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>95</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. According to this line, what is the predicted decrease in the test score for each additional hour spent on social media?
questions.explanation:
To find the predicted decrease in test score for each additional hour, we need to calculate the slope of the line of best fit. The slope m can be calculated using the two provided points, (x1,y1)=(1,95) and (x2,y2)=(6,70).

Using the slope formula:
m=y2-y1x2-x1=70-956-1=-255=-5
The slope is -5, which means the test score decreases by 5 points for every 1 hour increase in social media usage. Since the question asks for the 'decrease,' the answer is 5.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a question asks for the 'decrease' or 'loss' per unit, calculate the slope. If the slope is negative (e.g., -5), the decrease is the absolute value (5).

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math><mi>m</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants. If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>m</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a linear function, the slope m is given by the change in f(x) divided by the change in x. <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a linear function f(x) = mx + b, the slope m = (change in y) / (change in x) between any two points.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: Water is being pumped into a tank at a constant rate. After 20 minutes, the tank contains 180 gallons of water. After 35 minutes, the tank contains 315 gallons of water. At this rate, how many gallons of water were in the tank before the pumping started?
questions.explanation: Let V₀ be the initial volume and r be the pumping rate. From the given data: V₀ + 20r = 180 and V₀ + 35r = 315. Subtract the first equation from the second: (V₀ + 35r) - (V₀ + 20r) = 315 - 180 → 15r = 135 → r = 9. Substitute r = 9 into the first equation: V₀ + 20×9 = 180 → V₀ + 180 = 180 → V₀ = 0.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For linear rate problems, set up the equation: Final amount = Initial amount + (rate × time). Use two data points to solve for the two unknowns.

questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system: Multiply the second equation by 3: <math><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>57</mn></math>. Add to the first equation: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>57</mn></math> → <math><mn>14</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>74</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>14</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. Substitute into first equation: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>119</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mn>74</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>45</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>. Then <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>37</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>15</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>52</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sometimes it's faster to solve for a+b directly by manipulating the equations rather than solving for a and b separately.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,250 300,250 200,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='50' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><rect x='200' y='240' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='90' y='265' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='305' y='265' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='200' y='40' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>A</text><text x='200' y='265' font-family='Arial' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>D</text><text x='210' y='150' font-family='Arial' font-size='14'>8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Isosceles triangle ABC with vertex A at the top. An altitude AD drops from A to the base BC. The length of the altitude AD is labeled as 8.
questions.question: In the isosceles triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> shown above, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is the altitude to base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. The length of altitude <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn></math>. If the perimeter of triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>32</mn></math>, what is the length of the base <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
To solve for the base, we must use the relationship between the perimeter and the Pythagorean theorem.

1. Define variables: Let x be the length of the congruent sides AB and AC. Let y be the length of segment BD. Since the altitude in an isosceles triangle bisects the base, DC=y and the total base BC=2y.

2. Use the perimeter: The perimeter is given as 32.
AB+AC+BC=32
x+x+2y=32
2x+2y=32
x+y=16, which implies x=16-y.

3. Apply the Pythagorean Theorem: In the right triangle ABD:
BD2+AD2=AB2
y2+82=x2

4. Solve the system: Substitute x=16-y into the Pythagorean equation:
y2+64=(16-y)2
y2+64=256-32y+y2
Subtract y2 from both sides:
64=256-32y
32y=192
y=6

Since the base BC=2y, the length is 12.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When given a perimeter and an altitude, set up a system of equations where one equation comes from the perimeter sum and the other from the Pythagorean theorem.
